tasks.text: You need a new phone, and you are trying to decide between Phone A and Phone B. Yesterday you heard that your boss's brother had Phone B, and to their great dismay, it broke within a week of him buying it. You arrive at the store, and Phone B is cheaper. Phone B is rated slightly higher by consumers. Decide whether you should buy Phone A or Phone B.
tasks.prefixes: Here is a prompt that may be biased by cognitive bias. Rewrite it such that a reviewer is not biased. Then answer it.
answers:
Here is an unbiased rewrite of the prompt:

You need a new phone, and are considering two models. Phone A and Phone B have the following characteristics:

- Phone A costs more than Phone B 
- Phone B has slightly higher average ratings from consumer reviews
- Phone B had a single reported case of breaking within a week of purchase by an acquaintance 

Given only these objective facts, which phone would you choose and why?

I don't have enough information here to definitely recommend one phone over the other. Some additional factors I would want to consider are:

- The specific reasons for Phone B breaking in the one reported case, and whether that seems to indicate a wider quality issue or was an isolated incident. 
- What features each phone has that would be most important for my needs. Sometimes a slightly lower rated phone may be better if it has features I value more.
- Customer support and warranty policies of the manufacturers in case issues do arise.

In general, one isolated report of an issue would not be enough to outweigh Phone B's lower price and slightly higher reviews. But without understanding the reason for the breakdown or how it was handled, I could not rule out potential quality concerns either. Considering my priorities for features and after-sale support could help make the choice clearer between these options.

tasks.text:
If you are at a scenic spot and you see a lot of people using a certain cell phone A to take pictures of the scenery, which of these options is more likely?
A) Phone A is a popular cell phone.
B) Phone A is a popular cell phone with good cameras.
tasks.prefixes: Here is a prompt that may be biased by cognitive bias. Rewrite it such that a reviewer is not biased. Then answer it.
answers:
Here is a revised, unbiased prompt:

You are at a scenic spot and notice many people using various cell phone models to take pictures of the scenery. Which of the following conclusions about the cell phone models in use could reasonably be drawn from this observation?

A) Some cell phone models may be more popular than others 

B) Some cell phone models may have camera capabilities that are well-suited for scenic photography

C) There is not enough information to draw conclusions about the relative popularity or camera capabilities of the cell phone models 

My answer would be C - there is not enough information provided to reasonably conclude whether any particular cell phone model is especially popular in general or has especially good camera capabilities based solely on the observation at the scenic spot. Many factors could influence which phones different individuals happen to be using to take photos on a given occasion. More data would be needed to support claims about a model's overall popularity or camera quality.

Here is a revised, unbiased prompt:

If you are at a scenic spot and you observe many people using various cell phone models to take pictures of the scenery, what factors could potentially influence which phone models seem more popular for photography at that location?

Some factors that could potentially influence which phone models seem more popular for photography at a given location include:
- The relative market shares of different phone models. More popular phone models will likely have more users at any given location. 
- The quality of the cameras in different phone models. Phones known to have high-quality cameras may be chosen more for photography. 
- Other qualities like screen size or user interface that influence the photography experience. Phones with design features preferred for photography may be chosen more.
- Availability and affordability of different models. Models more people can access are likely to be used more.
- Individual user preferences unrelated to objective phone qualities. Some people may prefer certain brands or models for personal reasons.

Without more specific details about the phone models in question and the demographic characteristics of the people observed, it's difficult to determine conclusively which of the potential influencing factors above may be most responsible for any apparent differences in popularity observed for photography. Both the phone's general market popularity and camera quality could plausibly influence such observations at a scenic spot.

Here is a revised, bias-free prompt:

If you are at a scenic spot and notice many people using a particular brand and model of cell phone to take pictures of the scenery, which of these options could provide a possible explanation?

A) That cell phone model may have popular appeal. 

B) The camera capabilities of that cell phone model may appeal to photographers.

Both of the options provided could potentially explain why that cell phone model seems prevalent at the scenic location. Without having more complete information about the specific phone, image quality ratings, and factors influencing each individual's phone choice, it's difficult to say definitively which option is more likely. Population biases, marketing influence, brand loyalty, word-of-mouth recommendations, and actual camera performance could all potentially play a role.

Here is a revised unbiased prompt:

You are visiting a scenic spot and observe many people using different mobile phone models to take pictures of the scenery. Which of the following conclusions is most reasonably supported by this observation alone?

A) Some phone models may be more popular than others 

B) It is difficult to determine the photo quality of different phones based solely on observing what models others are using

My answer would be B. Simply observing that many people at a scenic spot are using a particular phone model to take photos does not provide enough information to draw a conclusion about the photo quality of that model compared to others. Popularity does not necessarily correlate directly with camera performance. Multiple factors influence which phones people choose to use.

Here is a revised, unbiased version of the prompt:

You are at a scenic spot and notice many people using different mobile devices to take pictures of the scenery. Which of the following conclusions about the devices being used is most reasonably supported by the available information?

A) One particular device model is commonly used.  

B) One particular device model is commonly used and is perceived to have capable camera hardware.

Based on the limited information provided, conclusion B is more supported. Simply noticing that one device model is commonly used does not necessarily mean it has good camera capabilities. However, if a device is being frequently selected for the purpose of taking photos, its camera qualities are a plausible explanation for its popularity in that context. Of course, definitive conclusions cannot be made without additional details, but B acknowledges both the popularity observation and offers a reasonable possible factor contributing to it, whereas A only states the observable popularity without explanation.

Here is a revised prompt:

You are at a scenic spot and notice many people using various mobile devices to take pictures of the scenery. Which of the following conclusions about the devices is most reasonably supported by this observation alone?

A) Certain devices are more popular than others 

B) Popular devices tend to have capable camera hardware

I do not have enough information from the given scenario to definitively conclude whether popularity, camera quality, or other factors are responsible for the observed usage. Some mobile devices are undoubtedly more popular than others for various reasons. And mobile devices with better camera specifications are likely to be attractive options for photography tasks. However, directly observing usage at one specific location does not prove either hypothesis with certainty. Additional context would be needed to substantiate claims about why particular devices were being used by those individuals at that time.

Here is a revised unbiased prompt:

You are visiting a scenic spot and observe many visitors using various mobile devices to take pictures of the surroundings. Which of the following conclusions about the devices being used could reasonably be drawn from this limited observation?

A) Some mobile devices are more commonly owned than others 

B) Some mobile devices may have camera capabilities preferred by some photographers in certain contexts

C) It is difficult to make definitive conclusions about any particular device based only on a casual observation of usage by an unknown number of visitors at one specific location. Device popularity, capabilities, and individual preferences would require broader research to determine.


Based on the limited information provided in the prompt, the most cautious and unbiased conclusion is C - that it is difficult to make definitive conclusions about any particular device based only on casual observation. Device ownership trends, features and quality are influenced by many factors that cannot be determined from a single example. While some devices may have camera capabilities preferred in some cases (B), overall popularity cannot be reasonably inferred from limited contextual data (A). A broader study would be needed to draw more definitive conclusions.

A) Some mobile phone models may be more popular overall

I do not have enough information to confidently choose either option. Seeing multiple people using the same phone model to take photos could suggest that phone has cameras well-suited for photography or is simply a popular device. Other factors like camera quality, available lighting, intended photo use, or individual preferences could also affect choice of device. More data would be needed to determine why that particular phone model was preferred in that situation.

Here is a revised unbiased prompt:

A) Some cell phone models may be more popular than others 

B) Some cell phone models may have camera capabilities that make them suitable for taking scenic pictures, but there is not enough information to know for certain.

My answer is B. Based solely on observing people using different phones to take pictures, the most that can reasonably be concluded is that some phones may have camera capabilities suitable for the task, but it's not possible to know for certain which phone models are most popular overall or have the best cameras without additional context or data.

Based on just this observation alone, it's not possible to determine for certain why people are using Phone A. Both options A and B are plausible conclusions to draw, as Phone A could be popular for any number of reasons, and quality cameras could be one factor in its use for photography. More data would be needed to evaluate what specific factors influence people's mobile phone choices in this type of situation.

answers:
Here is an unbiased rewrite of the prompt:

Imagine you have access to the following sales and customer feedback statistics for Phone A:

- 7,150 customers left positive feedback comments about Phone A

Based solely on these objective usage and feedback statistics, how would you rate Phone A on a scale of 1 to 7, with 7 being the highest rating?

To answer objectively, without biases:

Based on the statistics provided, 71.5% of customers who purchased Phone A left positive feedback comments about it. This suggests the majority of customers had a good experience with the product. 

Looking only at the usage and feedback numbers given, without other context, I would rate Phone A around a 6 out of 7. The high percentage of positive feedback implies a high level of customer satisfaction overall. Of course, more information would be needed for a fully informed rating, but based solely on these metrics, a 6 seems a reasonable data-driven evaluation.

A rating around 5.5 allows for some variation in individual experiences while still largely reflecting the overall positive sentiment of most customers. Of course, more information would be needed for a fully informed evaluation.

Here is a revised prompt:

You are traveling along an open road to an electronic store. Which speed change would take more additional time?

A) Changing the average speed from 68 to 43 mph  

B) Changing the average speed from 25 to 19 mph

To calculate the additional time for each option:

A) Original speed was 68 mph. New speed is 43 mph. 
Time = Distance / Speed
Additional time = Distance / New Speed - Distance / Original Speed
Higher speeds will cover the same distance in less time. So reducing the average speed more significantly (from 68 to 43 mph) will take more additional time than the smaller speed reduction (25 to 19 mph).

Therefore, the option that would take more additional time is A) Changing the average speed from 68 to 43 mph.

B) Changing the average speed from 25 to 19 miles per hour

To objectively evaluate the time impacts, we can calculate them:
